newsitem.title: USA: Dlr ends nearly unchanged vs mark, yen in U.S..
newsitem.headline: Dlr ends nearly unchanged vs mark, yen in U.S..

text.p: The dollar ended a volatile week on a quiet note, closing lightly mixed against other major currencies in thin, pre-holiday trade, dealers said.

A looming three-day holiday weekend in the two largest foreign exchange markets -- the United States and Britain -- and an early Friday close in most U.S. asset and derivative markets subdued trade volume and activity, dealers said.
The dollar inched lower to 115.60/70 by the close from 115.68/73 at the open and ended nearly flat at 1.6925/35 marks from 1.6924/27.
Stealing the spotlight was a sudden overnight drop in the Australian dollar, which shed over a full cent on news of an unexpected cut in official Australian interest rates.

The Reserve Bank of Australia surprised the markets by chopping 0.5 percentage points off the official cash rate, the fourth cut since last July, pushing the rate to 5.5 percent -- it's lowest since August 1994.
The Australian dollar closed at $0.7670, down from $0.7775 at Thursday's close.
The dollar showed little reaction to remarks overnight from Japanese Ministry of Finance official Eisuke Sakakibara, who was interviewed by French newspaper Le Monde.
Sakakibara said that a rise in Japan's discount rate should be expected by the end of the year.

"The discount rate is currently very low. If it rises by 0.5 percent, it will be at 1.0 percent, which remains low. A move on such a scale should be expected in the coming year," he said. He also noted, however, that he did not believe the Bank of Japan would raise rates before it was sure of a solid economic upturn.
Sung Won Sohn, chief economist at Norwest Corp, agreed with Sakakibara and said he expects official Japanese interest rates to be hiked sometime this summer.
"Economic growth is clearly gaining some momentum. Economic conditions are better than a lot of people realize in Japan right now and that should lead to higher interest rates," he said.

The first round of French parliamentary elections take place this weekend. Analysts said victory for the ruling centre-right coalition -- the expected outcome -- would bolster the dollar against the mark as the French franc should respond favorably.
But a left-wing win could hurt the U.S. unit as dealers buy marks.

"With the French elections this weekend, there is some anticipation that there may be a risk that the Socialists will get in. People have bought short-dated options that give them the right to own marks," said Russell LaScala, chief dealer at Citibank.
"It's a good risk-reward, low premium, high return option," he added.
Elsewhere, the dollar fell to 1.4028/38 Swiss francs from 1.4070/80 francs and the British pound recovered from Thursday's sell-off to end higher at $1.6342/52 from $1.6305/15.
The dollar gained to Canadian $1.3745/50 from C$1.3729/34. ((--Roanne Daniels, 212-859-1677))
